ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:0.5_0: 27. The long training rule on weavers

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.2_0: On one occasion a man who was walking to entering the wife had received his wife, telling him to have robe-cloth in this way.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.3_0: When I return I’ll give it to Venerable Upananda.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.6_0: In such-and-such a place I heard a man, as he was about to go away, tell his wife to have robe-cloth woven so that he could give it to you when he returned.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.8_0: And the weaver was Upananda’s supporter too.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.10_0: “This robe-cloth that you are weaving for me,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.10_1: make it long, wide, and closely woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.10_2: And make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.11_0: “Venerable, they’ve already weighed the thread and given it to me, saying,

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.14_0: But I’m able to make it well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.15_0: “Just make it long, wide, and closely woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.16_0: There won’t be any lack of thread.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.17_0: Then, when all the thread had been used up, that weaver went to that woman.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.17_1: He then said to her, “Madam, I need more.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.18_0: “But didn’t I tell you to weave the robe-cloth with that thread?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.19_0: “Venerable, I tell you to weave the robe-cloth with this thread.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.20_0: But Venerable Upananda told me to make it long, wide, and closely woven.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.21_0: And he said there wouldn’t be any lack of thread.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.22_0: That woman then gave him as much thread again as she had done the first time.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.27_0: “Please bring it, I’ll give it to Venerable Upananda.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.28_0: She then got the robe-cloth, gave it to her husband, and told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.29_0: After giving the robe-cloth to Upananda, he complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.30_0: “These Sakyan ascetics have great desires; they’re not content.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.31_0: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.32_0: How could Venerable Upananda go to the weavers and specify the kind of robe-cloth he wanted without first being invited by me?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.33_0: The monks heard the complaints of that man,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.34_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.35_0: “How can Venerable Upananda go to a householder’s weavers and specify the kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.36_0: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.37_0: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.41_0: “Foolish man, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.42_0: And still you went to the weavers of an unrelated householder and specified the kind of robe-cloth you wanted without first being invited.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.43_0: Foolish man, this won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.44_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.45.1_0: ‘If a male or female householder is having robe-cloth woven by weavers for an unrelated monk and, without first being invited, that monk goes to those weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.46_0: ‘This robe-cloth that you are weaving for me.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.46_1: to make it known and to the ear;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.46_2: make it closely woven, well-woven, well-stretched, well-scraped, and well-combed;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.47_0: and perhaps I will even give you a small gift;’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:1.48_0: then, in saying that and afterwards giving them a small gift, even if it is only a bit of almsfood, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.28_0: If the weaver makes it long or wide or closely woven because of the monk’s statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.29_0: When he gets the sitting-blanket, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.30_0: It should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.31_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.33_0: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth for which I went to the weavers of an unrelated householder and specified the kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited is to be relinquished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.34_0: I relinquish them to the Sangha.’ ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.37_0: ‘I give these tonics back to you.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.38.1_0: If the householder is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.39_0: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.40_0: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related and, without first being invited, he approaches the lay person’s weavers and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.41_0: If the lay person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.42_0: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np27:2.43_0: If the householders are related and he perceives them as such, there is no offense.
